virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would feel significant weight concentrated in the metal head, creating a distinctly top-heavy feel.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Straight shaft, ~30 cm long
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will wrap their dominant hand around the wooden shaft in a firm power grip, fingers curling fully and thumb locking over the index-middle fingers. The grasp point is roughly 12–15 cm below the metal head, giving a top-heavy moment that encourages wrist-centric swings. Typical motion is a rearward cocking of the forearm followed by a fast arcing swing driven by the shoulder and elbow and a final wrist snap to accelerate the head. On impact the user feels a sharp deceleration as the heavy head transfers momentum; the handle remains rigid with almost no give. After the strike the user may bounce slightly from the recoil and either re-grip for consecutive blows or relax the hand to rest the tool at their side.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would feel heftier mass concentrated in the hilt (about 500 g), with balanced weight distribution that doesn’t feel front-heavy.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users would overall feel a cylindrical shape while grasping with a diameter about 3cm
virtualObjectInfo.temperature: User would feel the surface cool to touch
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The cylindrical hilt is enclosed by one or two hands in a saber-style power grip: fingers curl around the 3 cm-diameter handle while thumbs align along the opposite side for stabilization. Users perform broad, sweeping arm motions—slashing, thrusting, and parrying—while constantly re-orienting the wrist for blade positioning. Because the virtual blade is weightless, the hilt feels balanced, allowing quick directional changes without front-loaded inertia. Each swing is met with negligible resistance until the beam meets an object, at which point the user feels a slight vibration or halt indicating a cut. Subtle twist or thumb-press gestures may be used to toggle activation, accompanied by a brief haptic bump that imitates an ignition switch.

virtualObjectInfo.outline: User would feel a straight handle while grasping
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user closes one hand around the cylindrical red handle in a medium power grip (fingers wrap, thumb opposite). Keeping the wrist neutral, they push the bar forward or pull it back along the guide rails. Travel is linear with about 10–15 cm range; moderate static friction must be overcome, then a smooth sliding resistance persists. At the end stops the mechanism halts solidly, conveying a firm stop that cues the user to reverse direction or release. Fine adjustments may involve small fore-aft pulses using primarily finger and wrist movement while the arm stabilizes the overall position.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: lightweight, about 10g
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users should feel a cylindrical shaped graspable part, with the narrow cross-section about 1cm in diameter.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users grasp the slim 1 cm-diameter shaft near its midpoint in a precision or tripod grip (thumb, index, and middle finger), similar to holding a pen. The wrist and fingers execute gentle, controlled strokes—dabs, swirls, and flicks—while maintaining light contact pressure to simulate bristle flex. The handle feels very light, so inertia feedback is minimal; instead, users rely on proprioception to guide delicate movements. Occasionally they may roll the brush between fingertips to change orientation, experiencing the smooth cylindrical outline with no perceptible resistance.

virtualObjectInfo.hardness: Users would feel soft and spring-back feedback, while squeezing and releasing an easily compressible part.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user pinches the soft rubber bulb between thumb and index finger while the glass stem rests lightly against the middle finger. Squeezing compresses the bulb with a compliant, rubbery give of several millimetres, accompanied by elastic resistance. Upon releasing, the bulb springs back, drawing virtual liquid into the tube—communicated by a brief suction haptic cue. To dispense, the user inverts the dropper and gradually squeezes again, producing rhythmic pulses that map to discrete droplet releases. Throughout, the overall device feels feather-light and delicate, encouraging gentle, controlled pinches rather than forceful grips.

virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user pinches the soft rubber bulb between thumb and index finger while the glass stem rests lightly against the middle finger. Squeezing compresses the bulb with a compliant, rubbery give of several millimetres, accompanied by elastic resistance. Upon releasing, the bulb springs back, drawing virtual liquid into the tube—communicated by a brief suction haptic cue. To dispense, the user inverts the dropper and gradually squeezes again, producing rhythmic pulses that map to discrete droplet releases. Throughout, the overall device feels feather-light and delicate, encouraging gentle, controlled pinches rather than forceful grips.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: an interactive creature for petting and combat
virtualObjectInfo.texture: Users would feel spiky surfaces as the slime will switch to defense mode while user’s hand approaching to it.
virtualObjectInfo.temperature: Users would feel noticeably warm when contact
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Interaction is primarily through open-hand petting, poking with fingertips, or tentative prods with the knuckles/backs of fingers. As the hand approaches, the creature transitions from a smooth, jelly-like surface to a defensive spiky texture: users first feel soft, yielding resistance that suddenly stiffens into localized sharp protrusions. Contact elicits spreading warmth, suggesting an internal heat. The slime deforms noticeably under pressure, bulging and reforming, and may recoil or jiggle after a tap. Touch duration is typically brief exploratory pokes or longer strokes when the creature is calm; during combat it may butt or shove back, creating reactive impacts on the user’s hand.

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: 5mm click release feature for the index finger
virtualObjectInfo.outline: grip part is about 7 cm tall and 4 cm deep
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The right hand forms a partial power grip around the 7 cm-tall, 4 cm-deep side grip, with the index finger resting over the 5 mm-travel shutter button. The thumb braces the rear while middle and ring fingers support from below. The left hand cups or pinches the lens barrel to steady aim or rotate focus/zoom rings with light rotational finger movements. To take a photo, the user depresses the shutter button through its short travel, feeling a distinct click before it springs back on release. The camera’s moderate mass gives it a solid, balanced feel, encouraging two-handed stabilization during aiming motions such as panning or tilting.

proxyLocation: left-center of the black tabletop in snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grip each end of the banana with one hand and rotate both wrists in opposite directions through roughly 90°

virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: Users would feel torsional resistance as perform rotational motion
virtualObjectInfo.outline: hands typically spaced 20 cm apart
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users approach the wheel, placing both hands diametrically opposite on the 24 cm-diameter rim—thumbs atop and fingers wrapping underneath. Employing a symmetric two-handed power grip, they rotate the wheel 90° clockwise or counter-clockwise. The motion is generated by forearm pronation–supination and shoulder rotation. As rotation begins, increasing torsional resistance is felt, simulating friction and fluid pressure in the pipe. The user must maintain grip force to overcome this resistance; once the valve reaches its hard stop at 90°, a pronounced stop feedback signals full open/close. Releasing returns the hands to neutral with no rebound, as the wheel stays fixed until actively moved again.

The user must maintain grip force to overcome this resistance; once the valve reaches its hard stop at 90°, a pronounced stop feedback signals full open/close. Releasing returns the hands to neutral with no rebound, as the wheel stays fixed until actively moved again.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: pressing the button with the palm
virtualObjectInfo.interactivity: Users should perceive a salient travel distance (~4 cm) with rising force.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Broad circular cap Ø ≈ 9 cm
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: rigid surface
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user brings an open palm (or sometimes a balled fist for dramatic effect) directly over the 9 cm-diameter cap and delivers a downward press. The contact begins with light surface touch on a flat, rigid disc; as force increases, the button travels downward about 4 cm against a nonlinear spring: initial light resistance followed by a steeper ramp. Near the end of travel a tactile detent clicks, confirming activation, after which the user releases pressure and feels the button rebound to its starting height. Interaction is brief and decisive, often accompanied by rapid hand withdrawal once actuation feedback is felt.

virtualObjectInfo.outline: Broad circular cap Ø ≈ 9 cm
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: rigid surface
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user brings an open palm (or sometimes a balled fist for dramatic effect) directly over the 9 cm-diameter cap and delivers a downward press. The contact begins with light surface touch on a flat, rigid disc; as force increases, the button travels downward about 4 cm against a nonlinear spring: initial light resistance followed by a steeper ramp. Near the end of travel a tactile detent clicks, confirming activation, after which the user releases pressure and feels the button rebound to its starting height. Interaction is brief and decisive, often accompanied by rapid hand withdrawal once actuation feedback is felt.
